title: Question 1

children: A 42-year-old woman with systemic sclerosis is evaluated for progressive dyspnea and exertional chest pain.
An apical four-chamber echocardiogram is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is pulmonary hypertension. The apical four-chamber echocardiogram view shows dilation of both the right atrium and right ventricle. On a normal apical four-chamber view, the right ventricle should be smaller than the left ventricle, but in this image, the right ventricle is significantly larger than the left. The right atrium also dwarfs the left atrium. Other echocardiographic findings in patients with pulmonary hypertension may include right ventricular hypokinesis, septal flattening or bowing toward the left ventricle, tricuspid regurgitation, pulmonary insufficiency, and midsystolic closure of the pulmonary valve.

objective.__html: Diagnose pulmonary hypertension.

figureCredits: Image reproduced with permission from Poch D, Mandel J. Pulmonary hypertension.

children: Ann Intern Med
A 62-year old woman is evaluated for an 8-month history of progressive dyspnea, dry cough, and clubbing. She continues to smoke cigarettes.
Chest CT scan is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
This patient's chest CT scan suggests idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. There are fibrotic cystic changes to the lungs, commonly called "honeycombing" because of their appearance, as
shown
arrow

). Honeycombing is a pathologic finding and not specific for a single disease, but it is commonly associated with advanced interstitial lung diseases, such as idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. The presence of honeycombing is associated with a poor prognosis.

objective.__html: Diagnose idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis on chest CT scan.

children: A 38-year-old woman is evaluated for a 10-week history of fever and dyspnea and infiltrates on chest radiography. She has received two courses of antibiotics with no improvement. She does not smoke cigarettes.
CT scan of the chest is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP). Patients with COP typically present with a 6- to 8-week history of cough, fever, and malaise. Initial chest radiographs will demonstrate patchy opacities that mimic pneumonia and, as a result, patients are often initially misdiagnosed with community-acquired pneumonia and treated with standard antibiotics. However, nonresolving symptoms and failure to respond to antibiotics should raise suspicion for organizing pneumonia or COP. High-resolution CT imaging will
demonstrate
ground-glass opacities (
red arrow
) or areas of alveolar consolidation (
black arrow

) resembling an infectious pneumonia, but findings can include peripheral nodules and nodules along the bronchovascular bundle. A nodular area of consolidation surrounded by a ground-glass appearance may be present and is referred to as the reverse halo or Atoll sign (not seen on this study).

objective.__html: Diagnose cryptogenic organizing pneumonia.

children: A 75-year-old man is evaluated for night sweats, weight loss, chest pain, and dyspnea.
Chest radiograph is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This chest radiograph is most consistent with a pleural-based tumor, which in this case is a mesothelioma. Right-sided multilobulated pleural-based opacification and pleural thickening are present. Although not seen in this patient, additional findings in mesothelioma include pleural effusion, decreased lung volume, and rib destruction. Other changes resulting from asbestos exposure (such as pleural effusion, pleural plaques, and asbestosis) are also often seen in combination with mesothelioma. This patient also likely has left lower lobe collapse, as suggested by the triangular area of opacification behind the heart, as
shown

objective.__html: Diagnose mesothelioma.

children: An 80-year-old man is evaluated for dyspnea following a large-volume gastric aspiration. He was admitted to the hospital 2 days ago with gram-negative sepsis.
Chest radiograph is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This chest radiograph shows left lung atelectasis caused by obstruction of the left main bronchus. There is diffuse, dense opacification of the left hemithorax. In addition, there is a loss of volume on the left, as indicated by the leftward movement of the mediastinum. Although mediastinal borders are difficult to discern, the absence of a right heart border to the right of the spine indicates the leftward movement of the heart. The heart's position can also be inferred by the leftward position of the pulmonary artery catheter.

objective.__html: Recognize the radiographic signs of left lung atelectasis.

children: A 52-year-old woman undergoes pulmonary function testing.
A flow-volume curve obtained during forced inspiration and expiration is
shown
(RV = residual volume; TLC = total lung capacity).
Which of the following is the most likely physiologic diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is variable intrathoracic upper airway obstruction. The flow-volume curve shown, which has an expiratory plateau, depicts the typical physiologic pattern of variable intrathoracic upper airway obstruction; “intrathoracic” in this case refers to the area below the thoracic inlet (where respiration-related changes in pleural pressure are transmitted to the airway). Flow is impaired during expiration rather than inspiration because the positive pleural pressure during forced expiration narrows the intrathoracic upper airway, whereas negative pleural pressure during forced inspiration widens the intrathoracic upper airway. An example of a variable intrathoracic obstruction would be a partially obstructing intrathoracic intraluminal tumor that was not circumferential, so that the available airway lumen varied in size during the respiratory cycle.

objective.__html: Diagnose variable intrathoracic upper airway obstruction on the basis of a flow-volume curve.

children: A 44-year-old man is diagnosed with COPD.
A frontal chest radiograph is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is α1-antitrypsin deficiency. α1-Antitrypsin deficiency should be considered in all patients with COPD, especially those who are younger than age 45 years; have a strong family history of COPD; have no identifiable COPD risk factors; or a have pattern of basilar emphysema. This posteroanterior chest radiograph shows absence of lung markings in the lower lobes consistent with basilar emphysema and the diagnosis of α1-antitrypsin deficiency.

objective.__html: Diagnose α1-antitrypsin deficiency.

children: A 53-year-old man with progressive dyspnea and cough is evaluated with a contrast-enhanced chest
CT
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
This contrast-enhanced chest CT scan suggests COPD. The multiple sharply defined areas of
low attenuation
are characteristic of centrilobular emphysema (
yellow arrow
). Paraseptal emphysema and bullae are seen in the subpleural lung regions (
red arrows

). These findings, with an appropriate clinical history and pulmonary function abnormalities, are consistent with a diagnosis of COPD. The diagnosis of COPD can be made with an appropriate supporting clinical history and spirometry. Radiography, including chest CT, is useful when the diagnosis is unclear or in patients with worsening symptoms suggesting a complication, such as infection or pneumothorax.

objective.__html: Recognize changes on a chest CT scan consistent with COPD.

children: A 17-year-old woman is evaluated for diarrhea, inability to gain weight, chronic cough, and recurrent episodes of bronchitis requiring antibiotic therapy.
Chest radiograph is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is cystic fibrosis (CF). Adults diagnosed with CF most often present with pulmonary or gastrointestinal symptoms. Pulmonary manifestations often include chronic productive cough, recurrent sinusitis, and recurrent pulmonary infections requiring recurrent courses of antibiotics. This chest radiograph
shown
suggests bronchiectasis. There are diffusely thickened bronchial walls (
arrows
) and pairs of parallel linear opacities (“tram tracks”) (
arrowheads

), consistent with bronchiectasis. Also seen are diffusely distributed patchy areas of airspace consolidation as well as mild hyperinflation of the chest; these findings are consistent with a diagnosis of CF.

objective.__html: Diagnose cystic fibrosis.

children: A 77-year-old man is evaluated for a cough.
Chest radiograph is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is asbestos-related lung disease. This chest radiograph
shows
multiple calcified pleural plaques (
arrows

). Pleural plaques typically involve the parietal pleura adjacent to ribs. Although plaques themselves are usually benign, they are markers of asbestos exposure. Mesothelioma usually presents as a dominant pleural-based mass.

objective.__html: Diagnose asbestos-related lung disease on chest radiography.

children: A 27-year-old asymptomatic woman is evaluated for incidentally discovered hilar enlargement on chest radiography.
CT
of the chest is performed.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is stage I pulmonary sarcoidosis (hilar lymphadenopathy with normal lung parenchyma). This chest CT scan
shows
lymphadenopathy. The scan is at a level just below the carina. It shows marked enlargement of lymph nodes in both hila (
white arrows
) and enlargement of a subcarinal lymph node (
black arrow

). Stage I pulmonary sarcoidosis is generally asymptomatic. Approximately 50% of all patients with pulmonary sarcoidosis show symptoms. (AAo = ascending aorta; DAo = descending aorta; LMB = left mainstem bronchus; RMB = right mainstem bronchus; RPA = right pulmonary artery.)

objective.__html: Diagnose sarcoidosis-related hilar lymphadenopathy on a chest CT scan.

children: A 23-year-old man is evaluated for sudden-onset chest pain and dyspnea. Focused ultrasonography is performed with the transducer placed on the lateral chest wall.
(Note that there is no sound for this
video
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is pneumothorax. This patient's ultrasound shows the “lung point sign,” which is consistent with pneumothorax. The soft tissue and two ribs are present in the near field, demonstrating that the examination is visualizing an intercostal space. Just underneath the
ribs

, a hyperechoic (white) line appears to slide in from the left of the screen and then goes off screen. This intermittent appearance of “lung sliding” with periods of no lung sliding in a single intercostal space is caused by a partially collapsed lung expanding to touch the parietal pleura of the chest during inspiration, then falling away during exhalation. The lung point sign has almost 100% specificity for pneumothorax.

Pleural effusion would be seen as a stable anechoic region in the chest cavity. Pneumonia would appear as an area of consolidation with B lines. Pneumonia may result in loss of lung sliding due to inflammation and small adhesions but does not typically cause a lung point. Pulmonary fibrosis on lung ultrasonography would result in a thickened, irregular pleural line, in addition to a diffuse B-line pattern. The pleural line is thin and normal in this clip.

objective.__html: Diagnose pneumothorax by using point-of-care ultrasonography.

children: A 37-year-old man is evaluated for sudden onset of dyspnea without chest pain.
ECG is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is pulmonary embolism. This patient's ECG demonstrates an S

Q3T3 pattern (prominent S wave in lead I, Q wave in lead III, and inverted T wave in lead III), which suggests pulmonary embolism. Although the ECG is of limited usefulness for the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism, abnormalities historically considered to support the diagnosis include an S

Q3T3 pattern, right ventricular strain, and new incomplete right bundle branch block. The most common ECG finding associated with pulmonary embolism is sinus tachycardia, but it is nonspecific and not helpful in establishing the diagnosis.

objective.__html: Identify ECG abnormalities suggestive of pulmonary embolism.

children: A 44-year-old man is evaluated for shortness of breath. Point-of-care ultrasonography of the lungs is performed. An ultrasound video with the probe placed at the left fifth intercostal space in the posterior axillary line is shown.
(Note that there is no sound for this
video
Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
This ultrasound finding is most consistent with a pleural effusion. The right of the screen
shows
the diaphragm (
white

) moving with respiration. The lung is visible moving in a large collection of fluid, which appears black. The vertebral bodies at the bottom of the screen, usually hidden by aerated lung, can be seen through the collection of fluid cephalad to the diaphragm.

A pneumothorax would present with a loss of “lung sliding,” which is the to-and-fro movement of the visceral pleura on the parietal pleura seen with respiration. Pneumonia is typically identified on ultrasonography by regions of lung that have a consolidated tissue-like appearance similar to the liver (“hepatization” of the lung). Often these regions are surrounded by focal B lines, an artifact generated by differences in density of the lung parenchyma resulting from increased fluid content. Neither is seen in this study. Pulmonary fibrosis on lung ultrasonography would appear as a thickened, irregular pleural line in addition to a diffuse B-line pattern.

objective.__html: Identify pleural effusion by using point-of-care ultrasonography.

children: A 79-year old man is evaluated for cough and dyspnea. He has a 70-pack-year history of cigarette smoking.
Chest
radiographs
are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is left mainstem endobronchial obstruction, most likely caused by a tumor. The chest radiographs
shown

indicate the presence of left upper lobe atelectasis. An ill-defined opacification is seen at the left hilum and left upper lung field. The hilum has been displaced laterally and superiorly, the trachea is deviated to the left, and the left hemidiaphragm has been elevated because of the loss of volume in the left upper lobe. Note the absence of the normally visible lucency of the left mainstem bronchus (
arrow,
left panel), possibly indicating its obstruction (a potential cause of left upper lobe atelectasis). The lateral radiograph reveals the anterior displacement of the major fissure (
arrows,
right panel) and an opacification of the left upper lung field.

objective.__html: Diagnose left mainstem bronchus obstruction.

children: A 51-year-old woman with unrefreshing sleep is evaluated with overnight polysomnography.
A representation of the polysomnogram is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is obstructive sleep apnea. Obstructive sleep apnea is an increasingly common disorder defined by sleep interruption due to repetitive upper airway narrowing or collapse. Disordered breathing events are most prominent during rapid eye movement (REM), a stage of sleep characterized by atonia of nearly all muscles, with the exception of the extraocular muscles and respiratory diaphragm. Efforts to breathe persist against the airway occlusion, resulting in intrathoracic pressure swings. The process is terminated with a brief awakening from sleep (called a microarousal), during which upper airway patency is restored and ventilation resumes, typically followed by resumption of sleep and continual repetition of the process. The polysomnogram demonstrates the association of airflow obstruction with periods of oxygen desaturation. Note the diminished airflow despite continuing muscular activity of rib cage and abdomen indicating airflow obstruction; in central sleep apnea, this muscular activity of the rib cage and abdomen would not be seen.

objective.__html: Diagnose obstructive sleep apnea.

children: A 56-year-old man is evaluated for a COPD exacerbation consisting of cough and voluminous sputum production.
Chest
radiographs
are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
These chest radiographs
show
right middle lobe atelectasis. The frontal chest radiograph reveals a vague density (
arrow

) partially obscuring the right heart border. On the lateral image, a triangular opacity is made by the complete atelectasis of the right middle lobe. As the right middle lobe collapses, the right major fissure is displaced anteriorly (
arrows
) and the minor fissure is displaced inferiorly (
arrowheads

). The right middle lobe atelectasis occurs more frequently than it does in other lobes. The reasons include the presence of lymph nodes that surround the right middle lobe bronchus, which may compress the bronchus if they are enlarged because of tumor or inflammation; less collateral ventilation; and increased airflow resistance due to the curved and narrow right middle lobe bronchus.

objective.__html: Diagnose right middle lobe atelectasis.

children: A 56-year-old woman is evaluated for wheezing and exertional dyspnea. Pulmonary function testing and a flow-volume curve are obtained.
The flow-volume curve obtained during forced inspiration and expiration is
shown
(RV = residual volume; TLC = total lung capacity).
Which of the following is the most likely physiologic diagnosis?

This flow-volume curve, which has both an inspiratory and an expiratory plateau, indicates a physiologic pattern of fixed upper airway obstruction; “upper airway” in this case refers to the airway above the level of the carina (the trachea or the larynx). The similar magnitude of the flow rates during inspiration and expiration demonstrates that the obstruction is “fixed” and does not vary depending on the phase of the respiratory cycle. A tracheal stricture composed of inflexible fibrotic tissue is an example of a fixed upper airway obstruction.

objective.__html: Diagnose fixed upper airway obstruction on the basis of a flow-volume curve.

children: A 48-year-old man is hospitalized following 4 weeks of cough and fever unresponsive to outpatient antibiotic therapy.
Chest CT scan is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is empyema. A pleural effusion associated with a bacterial pneumonia is called a parapneumonic effusion. It can be uncomplicated (sterile and free flowing) or complicated (infected or loculated). Uncomplicated effusions are typically small and resolve on their own with treatment of the pneumonia. Complicated parapneumonic effusions occur with significant inflammation or when bacteria invade the pleural space. An empyema is defined as a bacterial infection of the pleural space, which results in purulent fluid or a positive Gram stain. This patient's CT imaging
shows
enhancement of the pleura around the fluid creates a lenticular-shaped opacity (
arrows

), consistent with an empyema. This appearance is in contrast to a lung abscess, which is intraparenchymal rather than pleural based, often contains an air-fluid level, and has thickened irregular walls.

objective.__html: Diagnose empyema.

children: A 76-year-old man is evaluated for a 9-month history of progressive shortness of breath without cough or wheezing.
Chest CT
scans are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
These chest CT
findings
are consistent with asbestos-related lung disease as indicated by the presence of calcified pleural plaques on bone imaging (left panel,
yellow arrows
) and diffuse pleural thickening and basilar parenchymal fibrosis with parenchymal bands (right panel,
red arrow
) and curvilinear opacities (right panel,
black arrow

). Asbestosis refers to the slowly progressive, diffuse pulmonary fibrosis caused by inhalation of asbestos fibers. Patients developing asbestosis typically have a long latency period (often 20 to 30 years) after the initial exposure before becoming symptomatic. Diagnosis requires evidence of exposure (such as calcified pleural plaques), an appropriate latency period, a compatible clinical presentation (progressive dyspnea and reduced lung volumes and/or diffusing capacity), and consistent imaging results. High-resolution CT findings usually include pleural thickening and subpleural linear densities parallel to the pleura; basilar lung parenchymal fibrosis with peribronchiolar, intralobular, and interlobular septal fibrosis; and parenchymal bands.

objective.__html: Diagnose asbestos-related lung disease based on chest CT findings.

children: A 19-year-old woman is evaluated for the incidentally found 3-cm lung nodule
shown
. She does not smoke cigarettes.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is an arteriovenous malformation. The 3-cm nodular lesion seen at the base of the right lung is smooth, sharply circumscribed, and homogeneous in density; it is not associated with notable hilar or mediastinal lymphadenopathy. Nodular lung lesions are often caused by bronchogenic carcinoma or metastatic cancer. However, given this patient's age and nonsmoking status, a congenital or developmental lesion, such as an arteriovenous malformation, is more likely. In this case, a contrast-enhanced CT of the chest demonstrated the presence of an arteriovenous malformation.

objective.__html: Diagnose an arteriovenous malformation.

children: A 77-year-old man is evaluated for worsening cough, hemoptysis, and weight loss. He is a long-time cigarette smoker.
Chest
radiographs
are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The abnormality shown in these chest radiographs is most likely caused by right upper lobe endobronchial carcinoma. A homogeneous, sharply demarcated opacification is visible in the right upper chest on the frontal radiograph, accompanied by elevation of the right hemidiaphragm. Also seen is a modest superior and lateral displacement of the right hilum. The lateral chest film reveals opacification at the upper lung field. These findings are consistent with right upper lobe atelectasis. Lobar atelectasis is frequently caused by the obstruction of a bronchus by tumor, mucus plug, or aspirated material.

objective.__html: Diagnose right upper lobe endobronchial carcinoma.

children: A 51-year-old man is evaluated for acute onset of fever, chills, dyspnea, and nonproductive cough. He raises racing pigeons. Chest radiograph is normal.
Chest CT scan is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is hypersensitivity pneumonitis (HP). This patient's chest CT scan
shown
is compatible with HP, as demonstrated by patchy, bilateral ground-glass opacities (
red arrow
) and centrilobular micronodules (
blue arrow

) in the mid-lung section. Chest radiography can demonstrate diffuse micronodular disease but may be normal. Repetitive inhalation of antigens in a sensitized patient can result in HP, an immunologic response that results in noncaseating granulomas and peribronchial mononuclear cell infiltration with giant cells. The antigens are typically complex proteins, which can come from several sources. There are three forms of HP, and they each present differently. The acute form, which is most easily identified, results after a large exposure to an inciting antigen. The patient will develop fevers, cough, and fatigue, typically within 12 hours of exposure.

objective.__html: Diagnose hypersensitivity pneumonitis.

children: A 53-year-old man with emphysema is evaluated for progressive worsening symptoms and abnormal chest radiograph.
CT scan of the chest is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This chest CT scan demonstrates bullous lung disease. Bullae appear as hyperlucent areas on CT, sharply demarcated from surrounding lung by a thin wall. In this case, the bullae have caused compressive atelectasis of the right lower lobe and a leftward shift of the mediastinum. Bullae may represent severe localized disease or be associated with widespread emphysema, as in this case. Bullectomy may be a treatment option for patients with localized disease.

objective.__html: Identify bullae on chest CT.

children: A 56-year-old woman is evaluated with a chest
CT
following a motor vehicle accident.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A pneumothorax can be
seen
on this chest CT scan anterior to the right upper lobe and surrounding the trachea (
Tr
). The presence of air within the pleural space (pneumothorax) is indicated by a dark, hyperlucent area (
white arrowheads
). Subcutaneous emphysema (air within the soft tissues) is also seen (
black arrow

objective.__html: Diagnose a pneumothorax on a chest CT scan.

children: A 60-year-old man is evaluated for a 7-month history of progressive dyspnea and dry cough. He is a former cigarette smoker. Clubbing is present.
Chest radiograph is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This patient's frontal radiograph suggests the diagnosis of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. Chest radiographs in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis may demonstrate bibasilar septal line thickening with reticular changes and volume loss and bronchiectasis when the disease is more severe. The best diagnostic test is high-resolution CT, which may show abnormalities, such as bilateral-, peripheral-, and basal-predominant septal line thickening with honeycomb changes. Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis typically presents in patients between 50 and 70 years of age who have a greater than 6-month duration of a dry cough and dyspnea on exertion. Lung examination is notable for "Velcro" inspiratory crackles that are predominant at the bases. Clubbing is present in up to 50% of patients.

objective.__html: Diagnose idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis on chest radiography.

children: A 59-year-old man is hospitalized with acute hypoxemic respiratory failure requiring intubation.
A frontal chest radiograph is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This frontal chest radiograph reveals bilateral alveolar opacifications with air bronchograms, consistent with pneumonia. The right and left hemidiaphragms are each partially obscured, with placement of infiltrates in the right and left lower lobes, respectively. The right heart border is partially obscured, and an infiltrate within the right middle lobe is also possible.

objective.__html: Recognize the radiographic findings of multilobar pneumonia.

children: A 33-year-old man is evaluated for cough, shortness of breath, and a new pulmonary infiltrate. He received mantle radiation for Hodgkin disease 12 weeks ago.
Chest CT scan is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is radiation pneumonitis, which typically occurs 4 to 12 weeks after initial radiation exposure. High-resolution CT in radiation pneumonitis will demonstrate ground-glass opacities, usually within the field of radiation exposure. A well-defined nonanatomic demarcation between normal and abnormal lung consistent with the radiation field is pathognomonic but not always present. This patient's chest CT scan
shows
nonanatomic straight-line demarcating involved from non-involved lung parenchyma (
red arrows

). Patients with radiation pneumonitis present with cough, shortness of breath, and a new radiographic infiltrate. Fever, pleuritic chest pain, fatigue, and weight loss are accompanying nonspecific symptoms. Differential diagnosis often includes infection and drug-induced lung injury.

objective.__html: Diagnose radiation pneumonitis based on chest CT scan.

children: A 69-year-old man is evaluated for chronic dyspnea without cough. Pulmonary function testing is compatible with the diagnosis of COPD.
Chest
radiographs
are
shown
Which of the following conditions is the most likely radiographic diagnosis?

These chest radiographs show bullous lung disease. A bulla is a sharply demarcated air-containing space within the lung, surrounded by a smooth wall. Bullae appear as hyperlucent spaces, and hairline shadows often form their borders, distinguishing them from surrounding lung. In this patient, the virtual absence of lung markings in the right lower lung zone suggests a bulla in this region. Bullae may occur spontaneously or, more frequently, in the setting of obstructive lung disease. The latter is suggested in this case by findings such as hyperinflation, a flattened diaphragm, and an increased retrosternal air space. Bullae are not always apparent on plain chest radiographs.

objective.__html: Recognize radiographic signs of bullous lung disease.

children: A patient is evaluated for dyspnea. Focused ultrasonography of the lung is performed, with images obtained on both sides of the anterior and lateral chest.
(Note that there is no sound for this
video
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on the ultrasound findings?
This ultrasound video shows findings consistent with pulmonary edema. It depicts a hyperechoic (bright white) horizontal line in the near field moving with respiration (“lung sliding”) with vertical
hyperechoic lines
extending downward from the pleural line like lasers or search lights (B lines).

Analogous to Kerley B lines on a chest radiograph, a diffuse B-line pattern suggests interstitial thickening, most often caused by a fluid collection or pulmonary edema. Lung sliding and a B-line pattern throughout excludes pneumothorax, and pleural effusions will most often appear as anechoic (black) regions in dependent areas cephalad to the diaphragm.

objective.__html: Diagnose pulmonary edema by using point-of-care ultrasonography.

children: A 53-year-old woman with a diagnosis of previously treated breast cancer is evaluated for progressive dyspnea and cough.
Chest radiograph is
shown
Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The abnormalities
seen

on this frontal chest radiograph most likely suggest lymphangitic carcinomatosis. Lymphangitic carcinomatosis is defined by the presence of tumor within pulmonary lymphatics. The frontal radiograph shows bilateral prominent interstitial markings. Also seen here is a moderate left and small right pleural effusion, as well as hilar lymphadenopathy (
black arrowhead
). In the setting of pleural effusions and hilar lymphadenopathy, the interstitial disease is compatible with lymphangitic carcinomatosis. Both Kerley A lines and Kerley B lines (
red arrow

), when present, may also be helpful, as they indicate infiltration of the interstitial space by either fluid (as seen in pulmonary edema) or cells (as in lymphangitic carcinomatosis). Lymphangitic carcinomatosis is the most likely diagnosis given the patient's past history of breast cancer, presenting symptoms, and radiographic findings.

objective.__html: Diagnose lymphangitic carcinomatosis.

children: A 68-year-old woman with dyspnea is evaluated with chest
CT
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
This chest CT scan
shows
bilateral small pleural effusions, indicated by smooth opacifications within the pleural space (
white arrows

). The effusions appear to be layering in the most dependent spaces in this supine patient. In contrast, chest images in mesothelioma commonly show a unilateral pleural abnormality with a large, unilateral pleural effusion.

objective.__html: Recognize pleural effusions on a chest CT scan.

children: A 70-year-old man is evaluated for progressive dyspnea.
Chest
radiographs
are
shown
Which of the following diagnoses is most consistent with these radiographic findings?

These chest radiographic findings are consistent with an obstructive lung disease, such as COPD. The frontal chest radiograph shows hyperinflation and increased lucency and decreased vascularity throughout both lung fields. The lateral chest radiograph demonstrates flattening of the diaphragm and increased retrosternal air space. However, COPD is a clinical rather than radiographic diagnosis, and an appropriate history and pulmonary function test results are required to make the diagnosis.

objective.__html: Recognize radiographic findings consistent with COPD.

children: A 30-year-old woman is evaluated for an incidentally found abnormality on a contrast-enhanced chest
CT
scan.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This image from contrast-enhanced CT of the chest reveals a well-circumscribed nodule within the left upper lobe. Nodules are less than or equal to 30 mm in size, whereas masses are greater than 30 mm. No other discrete nodular infiltrates are noted on this image, although differentiating an enhancing nodule from a vessel may be difficult without the use of multiple contiguous images. Vessels, however, become progressively smaller in diameter with distance from the hilum, whereas the contrast-enhancing finding shown here is clearly larger than vessels much closer to the hilum.

objective.__html: Recognize a solitary pulmonary nodule on a chest CT scan.

children: A 41-year-old woman is evaluated for subacute cough. She reports aspirating a peanut 2 weeks ago.
Chest
radiographs
are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This patient's chest radiographs show atelectasis of the right lower lobe. On the frontal chest radiograph, a triangular opacity in the right lower lung field is demarcated by the sharp, oblique border of the inferiorly and medially displaced major fissure, as
shown
arrows

). Note also that the right interlobar pulmonary artery is no longer visible on the frontal radiograph, because it is obscured by the collapsed lower lobe. Similarly, the hemidiaphragm border is obliterated, suggesting a lower lobe process. The lateral film
shows
a vague triangular opacity (
arrows

) obscuring the lower thoracic vertebrae, caused by the collapsed right lower lobe. The right bronchus, particularly the mainstem or divisions of right lower lobe bronchus, is the most common site of aspiration for adults; this is because of its more vertical angle and larger diameter compared with the left.

objective.__html: Recognize the radiographic signs of right lower lobe atelectasis.

children: A 58-year-old woman with septic shock is admitted to the ICU. A central venous catheter is placed. Follow-up chest
radiography
is performed.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
This chest radiograph
shows
a right pneumothorax following the placement of a right subclavian catheter. The catheter tip is approximately at the junction between the superior vena cava and the right atrium (
black arrow
). An edge demarcating the abrupt end of parenchymal lung tissue (
white arrowheads
) is seen. The air-filled pneumothorax is lateral to this edge and darker than the adjacent lung, which lies medial to the edge.

objective.__html: Diagnose pneumothorax.

children: A 65-year-old man is admitted to the hospital with a COPD exacerbation characterized by increased cough and sputum production. He is emergently evaluated 24 hours after admission for acute on chronic respiratory failure.
Chest radiograph is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is right mainstem bronchus mucous plug. This chest radiograph
shows

opacification of the right hemithorax, caused by right lung atelectasis. Atelectasis is the loss of gas within the lung, which reduces volume. In this case, atelectasis of the right lung has caused a rightward shift of the mediastinum, indicated by the rightward displacement of the trachea from the midline (
arrow
) and the left mainstem bronchus away from its normal position within the left hemithorax (
arrowhead
). Right lung atelectasis may be caused by an obstruction within the right mainstem bronchus, such as an endobronchial tumor or large mucous plug, as in this patient.

A massive pleural effusion could similarly cause complete opacification of the right hemithorax but would not result in a rightward deviation of mediastinal structures; if large enough, a right-sided effusion could cause leftward displacement of mediastinal structures. Similarly, pneumonia would be unlikely to cause mediastinal shift.

objective.__html: Diagnose right lung atelectasis secondary to endobronchial obstruction.

children: A 19-year-old woman is evaluated for dyspnea with pulmonary function testing.
A flow-volume curve obtained during forced inspiration and expiration is
shown
(RV = residual volume; TLC = total lung capacity).
Which of the following is the most likely physiologic diagnosis?

This flow-volume curve, which has an inspiratory plateau, shows the typical physiologic pattern of variable extrathoracic upper airway obstruction; “extrathoracic” in this case means above the thoracic inlet (i.e., above the level at which respiration-related changes in pleural pressure are transmitted to the airway). Flow is impaired during inspiration rather than expiration because the negative intraluminal pressure during inspiration narrows the extrathoracic upper airway, whereas positive intraluminal pressure during expiration widens the extrathoracic upper airway. An example of a variable extrathoracic obstruction would be a partially obstructing extrathoracic intraluminal tumor that was not circumferential, so that the available airway lumen would vary in size during the respiratory cycle.

objective.__html: Diagnose variable extrathoracic upper airway obstruction on the basis of a flow-volume curve.

children: A 49-year-old man is evaluated for chronic cough and voluminous sputum production.
Chest CT scan is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is bronchiectasis. The patient's chest CT scan
shows
typical findings of bronchiectasis (airway dilatation with lack of tapering [
green arrow
]; bronchial wall thickening [
yellow arrow
]; and cysts [
red arrow

]). An additional finding in bronchiectasis is a signet ring appearance, which occurs when the diameter of the bronchus in cross-section view is larger than the adjacent pulmonary artery. This manifests as a round or oval opacity representing a dilated bronchus and a smaller adjacent opacity representing its pulmonary artery.

objective.__html: Diagnose bronchiectasis on a chest CT scan.

children: A 53-year-old man is evaluated for long-standing dyspnea and cough.
ECG is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely electrocardiographic diagnosis?

Electrocardiographic findings characteristic of right atrial enlargement are tall (≥2.5 mm), peaked P waves (P pulmonale) in leads II, III, and/or aVF, as seen in this patient's ECG. Although not seen on this ECG, a P wave greater than 1.5 mm tall in V
or V
may indicate right atrial enlargement.

objective.__html: Identify features of right atrial enlargement on ECG.

children: A 78-year-old man with severe COPD is evaluated for worsening dyspnea.
ECG is
shown
Which of the following conditions is demonstrated on this patient's ECG?
This ECG demonstrates right ventricular hypertrophy. Specific findings include a dominant R wave in V
, persistent S waves in V
through V
, a right ventricular strain pattern, and probable right atrial abnormality. The ECG features suggestive of right ventricular hypertrophy include the following:
Tall R wave in lead V
Persistent precordial S waves
Evidence of right atrial enlargement
Right axis deviation or indeterminate axis
rSr' in lead V
Right ventricular strain pattern
The presence of several of these features supports a diagnosis of right ventricular hypertrophy.

objective.__html: Identify ECG features of right ventricular hypertrophy.
